name: "Evening of Kirtan" at The Yoga Lounge
description:
You are warmly invited to join us for an evening of interactive musical mantra meditation (kirtan). Kirtan is a call-and-response form of meditation, utilizing ancient eastern mantras, traditional instruments and our very own voices.

This event will present an opportunity to explore your sacred heart space through the power of music and mantras. The practice of kirtan can tap into deep states of consciousness but can also invoke exciting feelings of joy and energy.

Presenting this special workshop will be members of the Kirtan Culture Initiative who have been sharing kirtan in various capacities throughout Toronto for close to 15 years. We hope to see you there!

name: Linocut Reduction Printmaking Workshop

location.name: High Park Nature Centre Forest School

description:
Note: Pre-registration is required for all our events, hikes and workshops. We do this to ensure we don’t exceed our capacity for indoor events or the maximum limits for group sizes on High Park’s ecologically sensitive trails.

Learn the art of Linocut Reduction Printmaking and come away from this two-part ambitious beginner workshop with colourful prints inspired by nature. You’ll learn every stage of the process and will take away eight 5×7 prints, plus the knowledge of how to set up a linocut workspace at home.

name: Spring Into Art: A Danforth CTI Art Show
description: You are cordially invited to attend our inaugural art show, featuring the work of students in grades 9-12. Enter through the main doors and tour the historic, century old building and our renowned art facilities to see work from various disciplines including painting, drawing, printmaking, film photography, ceramics and digital media.

name: Līlai: A Yoga Workshop for Joy & Exploration at Scarborough Museum
description:
Join Madura Siva-Nandakumar and Scarborough Museum and reconnect with your inner child in this uplifting yoga workshop centered around the theme of play. Through creative movement, partner poses, laughter, and lighthearted flow, we’ll explore freedom on the mat and in the mind. No pressure, just presence—come as you are and let your spirit move!

Madura is a holistic health advocate and the founder of Advaita Movement, a wellness hub that intentionally serves the community through yoga classes, Marma massage therapy sessions, Ayurvedic workshops and the Advaita Movement health and wellness shop. Her vision is to one day open a holistic wellness centre accessible to all.

name: Spring Bird Festival
description:
Enjoy a full day of guided bird walks, live birds, reptiles and amphibians, free native plant giveaways, children’s activities, and environmental educational displays. Bird walks start regularly throughout the festival on the hour for older learners, and the half hour for kids and kids at heart.

Toronto is a well-established stopover and home to over 270 bird species, making it a top destination for bird lovers.

Come celebrate nature in the city and learn how we can all help protect and support our feathered friends.

Dogs are welcome—please keep them on a leash.

name: SOLD OUT - Ready Player One: A Dive into Toronto’s Video Game Industry
description: Video game production is a key creative technology industry in Toronto, housing the majority of Ontario’s 298 video game companies. Join us for this panel conversation exploring the ways art, urban design and history all intersect in the gaming industry. Learn more from the creators of Toronto-based games, what inspires them, and how video games root us in place and culture. Featuring speakers ranging from independent game designers to powerhouse companies, this talk invites community members of all ages to discover the joys of engaging with video games. It includes a panel discussion followed by a Q&A segment.

name: TEMPERED

location.name: The Creative School Chrysalis, Toronto Metropolitan University

description:
Featuring World Premieres by Florida-based Peter Chu and Artistic Director, Deborah Lundmark, with audience favourites by Jennifer Archibald, Colin Connor, and Roderick George highlighting the company’s annual home season of cutting-edge contemporary dance.

...simply breathtaking
- Michael Crabb, Dance International​

​CCDT can take its place among the ranks of Toronto’s top dance companies.
- Paula Citron, The Globe and Mail

name: The Triumphs & Tragedies of Toronto's Sports Icons
description: You can learn a lot about a city through the stories of the athletes it has celebrated and cheered on. Toronto’s past is filled with dramatic tales of sports heroes who have brought us championships and heartbreak – and shaped our city in the process. In this walk, we’ll trace that history through downtown Toronto and the waterfront, visiting long-lost stadiums, exploring Edwardian victory parades and uncovering stories of forgotten glories. Discover inspiring tales about icons – from Tom Longboat to Terry Fox, and Babe Ruth to Joe Carter – and learn about the impact their athletic exploits have had on the city’s identity.

name: Indigenous Storytelling Workshops with John Keeshig Mayawaasige

location.name: Spirit Garden Teaching Lodge at Nathan Phillips Square

description:
John Keeshig Mayawaasige is an Anishnaabe Knowledge Keeper from Neyaashiinigmiing First Nation. His work focuses on preserving Indigenous knowledge and teachings, which are integral to his creating sacred spaces like the new Teaching Lodge at the Spirit Garden at Nathan Phillips Square.

Participants will learn from John on his vision and inspiration for the Teaching Lodge. As a sacred building, the Teaching Lodge is imbued with cultural knowledge and symbolism. John will captivate with his storytelling and enrich the cultural awareness of participants. Each workshop is 45 minutes long.

Please arrive early to ensure seating.

name: From Ballparks to Backstage: A Legacy of Play in Toronto's Riverside

address.streetAddress: Riverside Common Park, 657 Queen St E

description: Explore Riverside through the lens of play. “From Ballparks to Backstage” shares many facets of play through time and space, as commemorated by unique public art, plaques and reflections from community members. Uncover Riverside’s rich sports heritage, from Sunlight Park – Toronto’s first baseball grounds – to historic bicycle races and curling on the Don River. Experience the revitalization of Joel Weeks Park, a vibrant public space featuring playful art. Finally, dive into Riverside’s theatrical history with stories of The Opera House, Teck Theatre, Comedy Alley and more. Join us for a journey that’s as fun as it is fascinating.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/From Ballparks to Backstage A Legacy of Play in Toronto's Riverside Neighbourhood_2wIPYvUwcLvuSgpsQGmRag.jpg

name: Doors Open at Colborne Lodge
description:
In 1874 British immigrants Jemima and John Howard donated their land to the City of Toronto to become beautiful High Park. Historical records indicate that the Howards were avid players of board games. Join interpretive staff for a rare chance to see historic board games from the 1800s. Howard created his own version of a popular game from this era known as Steeple Chase. Visitors will have the opportunity to play a round of this game and learn about its history! 

Lawn games will also be offered for a full family fun day of play!

name: Doors Open at Fort York
description: This Doors Open Toronto weekend, come visit Fort York National Historic Site, and delve into the fascinating history of this War of 1812 site and the many people who call this place their home! Tours and demonstrations happening throughout the day! You're invited to explore the City's most iconic buildings, as visitors are encouraged to get out and play as they discover their city!

name: Doors Open Toronto at Spadina Museum
description: Visit Spadina Museum for Doors Open and step back in time to discover Toronto in the 1920's.  Learn about what adults and children alike did for fun in their leisure time. Enjoy the beautiful gardens in full bloom!

name: Toronto Bonsai Society's 2025 Spring Exhibition and Sale
description:
Step into a world of nature's beauty and timeless tradition. In the heart of the season of renewal, enjoy this unique exhibition celebrating artistry, patience and the serenity of bonsai cultivation.

Explore an inspiring collection of expertly trained bonsai trees in full seasonal bloom, from delicate flowering species to ancient gnarled specimens that tell stories of decades of care and styling.  Whether you're a seasoned bonsai enthusiast or simply looking for a peaceful and awe-inspiring experience, this event offers something for everyone!

name: Scented Candle Making Workshop
description: Learn a new skill with this fun and relaxing activity. Select personalized scents, and work with organic soy wax which burns cleaner, and lasts longer. Take your candles home with you that day and enjoy your new custom scented creations.

name: Sold Out - Liminal Assembly x Doors Open | Lost in the PATH Walking Tour

location.name: Atrium on Bay, Northeast corner of Dundas St. and Bay St.

description: Join us as we venture deep down into the digestive tract of the city, exploring the nooks and crannies of the forlorn Toronto PATH system. We may get lost, but we’ll find ourselves in the process. As seen on Global News, CBC and BlogTO, Liminal Assembly  runs odd and surreal events focused on nostalgia, childlike play and liminal spaces, all in the pursuit of feeling rare emotions. See you in the backrooms.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/LIMINAL ASSEMBLY x Doors Open  Lost in the PATH Walking Tour_1l_CmcIxUhKGdu_qIJpyIA.jpg

name: 2nd Annual Turtles on the Move Parade

location.name: High Park (Parade starts at the park entrance on Bloor)

description: Led by Grandmother Vivian Recollet, the parade will feature turtle puppets made by Ange Loft (Kanien'kehá:ka, from Kahnawà:ke, QC),  Shadowland Theatre, Clay and Paper Theatre, Indigenous Drummers and Singers, Maracatu Mar Aberto and volunteers from turtle protection groups across Ontario.

name: Rexdale: A World of Cultures, One Step at a Time

location.name: 2280 Islington Ave, meet at Cash Money parking lot

description: Step into Rexdale, where cultures from around the world come together to create a vibrant, ever-changing playground of flavours, music and history. Explore a multicultural mall buzzing with energy, where every meal is a passport to a different country. Stroll through parks alive with community spirit, discover buildings that have played new roles since the 1960s, and feel the rhythm of a neighbourhood that never stops evolving. Venture just a little farther to Woodbine Centre, built atop a 1950s racetrack, where history and modern life collide. In Rexdale, every street is a stage, every meal a celebration, and every turn an invitation to play.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/Rexdale Enjoy many neighbourhoods with one culture at a time_ZzIXmXvYshyxZlkhVL8p-Q.JPG

name: Party 4 Paws Pet Fair
description:
Join us a family-friendly event celebrating pets, local and international animal rescues, and the pet-loving community!

What to Expect:
 
Meet adoptable pets & support local and international rescues

Shop from amazing pet-friendly vendors

Enjoy games, giveaways & interactive activities

Strike a pose at our pet photo booth

Enter raffles for a chance to win great prizes!

Whether you’re a pet parent or just love animals, this is the perfect way to spend the weekend. Bring your furry friend (on a leash, please!) and join us for an unforgettable celebration of pets and community.

name: Estonian Music Week 2025: Curly Strings, The Crosslegs, Les Rats d'Swompe
description:
A countryside dance party in the heart of the city. Nordic bluegrass meets Franco-Ontarian folklore meets Irish-inspired folk rock for one unforgettable night. 

Curly Strings (EST)
Bold bluegrass renovators. Curly Strings is an acoustic four-piece band that draws its inspiration from their own personal heritage in the current Estonian cultural space.

The Crosslegs (EST)
Energetic folk rock with an Irish flair. 

Les Rats d'Swompe (CAN)
Introducing people to the sound of the traditional violin, call and response songs, and the musicality of the yesteryear. 

This event is part of the Estonian Music Week (EMW) festival programme running May 22-25.

name: Official Estonian Music Week Afterparty: Dumai Dunai • Estonian Music Week 2025
description:
Join us for the EMW's official Friday night afterparty! Headlining the show, and in charge of getting your feet moving, are Dumai Dunai along with some surprise special guests.

Dumai Dunai
Slavic dub-punk missionaries Dumai Dunai have been winning the hearts of audiences all over the world since they first burst onto the scene in 2022. Dumai Dunai exists somewhere between the underground scene of their beloved Montreal and the mountains and valleys of their Slavic homelands.

Estonian Music Week 2025 festival
This event is part of the Estonian Music Week (EMW) festival programme.

name: A Tribute to Toronto's Unofficial Mascot: Racoon Park
description:
Join O2 Planning + Design for a guided walk exploring the design of Toronto’s newest park at Yonge and Eglinton. Created as a playful escape in the urban landscape, Raccoon Park was designed with children in mind and features a unique, custom-built, climbable wooden raccoon face as its centerpiece. 

The park, which embraces Toronto’s love-hate relationship with its unofficial mascot, also includes a playground, a splash pad, shade structures, seating, grassy areas and native plant life. Learn how the park blends play and urban design while celebrating Toronto’s most famous urban wildlife.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/Play and Whimsy in the City Raccoon Park_ggQ08_5bN-_cD8Wh-WqG0Q.jpg

name: Playground Tours with Architects: St. Andrew’s Playground Park
description: St. Andrew’s Playground Park, Toronto’s oldest downtown playground, first opened in 1908 and was recently revitalized by design firm DTAH. Nestled in the Fashion District, the park now features playful seating, a robust tree canopy and vibrant yellow accents that unify the space. Join the Toronto Society of Architects (TSA) and DTAH for a tour led by the revitalization team, discussing the integration of playfulness, the preservation of heritage trees and the design challenges of reimagining the space. This is one of three TSA-led tours at Doors Open Toronto 2025 focusing on playground design.

name: Doors Open at Todmorden Mills
description:
Tucked away in the Don Valley, have fun and play at Todmorden Mills!

Sip on a mocktail in the Papermill Gallery and be immersed in the vibrant calypso performances by Kaiso Street Combo.

Tour two historic houses, slipping back in time to when this site was an industrial hub, and enjoy playing with historical games and crafts. 

Feel the breeze of a warm spring day through the Wildflower Preserve, park grounds, and connect with local community partners.

organizer.name: Toronto History Museums: Todmorden Mills Heritage Site

name: From Stage to Field: The History of Public Entertainment at Exhibition Place

location.name: Dufferin Gate, 14 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3

description: Located on 192 acres along the shore of Lake Ontario, Exhibition Place has provided visitors with entertainment for nearly 150 years. It has been home to major events like the Canadian National Exhibition and the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair, Toronto’s professional sports teams, concert venues and festivals. This tour explores the site’s green spaces and heritage architecture, and includes stops at the Music Building and the iconic Bandshell. Join in celebrating Toronto’s largest event space, now hosting over 1,760 events each year.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/From Stage to Field The History of Public Entertainment at Exhibition Place_otewhM5BPO-AbUXSmw-VkA.jpg

organizer.name: Doors Open Toronto - City of Toronto

name: Community Environment Day at Dieppe Park
description:
Join Councillor Fletcher (Ward 14) and the City of Toronto to help reduce the amount of waste going to landfill. Drop off household items for donation, electronics for reuse or recycling and household hazardous waste for proper disposal. 

Pick up free bagged compost while supplies last and kitchen catchers for organics ($7 each – cash, debit and credit accepted).

name: Sold Out - Guided Mural Double-Decker Bus Tours

location.name: Parking lot of Montgomery's Inn Museum

description: Experience the west-end neighbourhood of the Village of Islington, also known as the Village of Murals, from a bird's-eye view aboard a double-decker bus. Encounter 26 stunning murals in this outdoor art gallery as you embark on a 200-year historical journey starting at Montgomery's Inn, a Toronto History Museum. With the opportunity to hop off the bus for a closer look at the award-winning art pieces by artists like Sarah Pollard and John Kuna, attendees will be immersed in the intricate historical details and stories behind each creation, guided by knowledgeable experts who reveal the execution and techniques involved in bringing these murals to life.

name: Playground Tours with Architects: Sara Jackman Playground

location.name: Sara Jackman Playground at the University of Toronto Dr. Eric Jackman Institute of Child Study

description: The playground at the University of Toronto’s Dr. Eric Jackman Institute of Child Study (JICS), now called the Sara Jackman Playground, has been reimagined by PLANT Architect Inc. This bright, multi-level play environment enhances accessibility and supports JICS’s goal of fostering creative play to promote mental and physical development while strengthening connections to nature. Join the Toronto Society of Architects (TSA) and PLANT for a guided tour led by the design team, covering the story behind the playground’s transformation, the lessons learned and the principles of designing for risk, creativity and social impact. This is one of three TSA-led tours at Doors Open Toronto 2025 focused on playground design.

name: Guild Park: Playground for the Arts
description: Guild Park & Gardens, located along the Scarborough Bluffs, inspires artists and art lovers alike. This one-hour tour takes you through Canada’s first artist community, showcasing historic artists’ studios, sculptures and architecture. Highlights include a visit to the restored artist’s studio, a walk through gardens with bronze and steel sculptures, and a glimpse of the unique Greek Theatre, where actors demonstrate the performance experience. The tour also includes a visit to the Clark Centre for the Arts, featuring contemporary artists.

name: SING! The Toronto International Vocal Arts Festival
description: Canada’s premier a cappella music festival returns with more than 20 events, including concert performances, industry workshops, and the inaugural championships. Special guests include singer-songwriter Steven Page and legendary vocal producer Deke Sharon.

organizer.name: SING! The Toronto International Vocal Arts Festival

name: Doors Open Toronto at Gibson House
description: Visit Gibson House for Doors Open Toronto, an open invitation to explore the city's most-loved buildings and sites. This year, get ready to join in and "Get Ready to Play" inside and outside the museum.

organizer.name: Gibson House Museum - City of Toronto Museums and Heritage Services

name: Identity: A Song Cycle

location.name: Marilyn and Charles Baillie Theatre (Berkeley Street Theatre)

description:
In early June 2020, Torontonian and baritone Elliot Madore opened up on social media about his struggles with “unabashedly expressing [his] identity” as a biracial person.

Together with director Joel Avany, Madore seeks to find a way to present to the Canadian arts community the universal themes behind his moving Instagram post. In collaboration with genre-bending composer Dinuk Wijeratne and acclaimed poet Shauntay Grant, Against the Grain (AtG) and Madore will present a song cycle that sets new and original Canadian poetry to music that blends Western classical music with an array of musical traditions, including those from South Asia and the Middle East, as well as modern pop and jazz idioms.

name: Akin Davisville Open Studio - Doors Open Toronto 2025
description: As part of this city-wide celebration of Toronto’s architectural, cultural, and creative spaces, Akin Davisville will open its studio doors to the public for the very first time. Visitors will get a behind-the-scenes look at the incredible work and community.

name: Doors Open at Etobicoke Lawn Bowling Club
description: Come and learn about the resurgent sport of Lawn Bowls and even roll a few bowls yourself.

name: Prohibition
description:
Enter through a tucked away entrance to step into an evening shaped by secrecy, indulgence and booze. Prohibition is part cocktail party, part cabaret all set in a historic building that played a role in Toronto’s booze-running scene.  

Expect classic cocktails reimagined, a menu that traces the tastes of the era, and a setting that unfolds around you. Burlesque dancers will keep you entertained, a magician will keep you on your toes, and jazz will keep you on your toes. 

Choose your night: take a tour, find the dance floor, follow the magic. Or stay still and let it all come to you.

name: Doors Open at Scarborough Museum
description:
Scarborough Museum brings home the theme "The City Is Your Playground; Get Ready to Play" by highlighting belonging, community and history at one of Scarborough's most culturally and historically significant sites. Visitors are invited to reflect on the complexities of play, joyful yet mindful of the profound histories of loss, and engage with contemporary and historical stories.

Embrace the playful spirit of the area's identity and traditions with lightness and reverence. During Doors Open, the museum's heritage buildings provide a dynamic space where the past and present intertwine, revealing Scarborough's diverse roots through engaging activities, treats and games.

The museum will also feature ReDress, a powerful art installation by waⁿdat utrihǫt and multidisciplinary artist Catherine Tàmmaro, raising awareness about Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and Two-Spirited Peoples (MMIWG2S).

name: Estonian Music Week 2025: Estonian Voices, Countermeasure
description:
A capella jazz innovators blending folk, pop, and jazz into ethereal vocal harmonies - this is Estonian Voices. What better pairing for the vocal sextet from Estonia than the powerful voices, beautiful harmonies and a fresh take on the vocal jazz genre by Canada's own Countermeasure.

Presented in partnership with SING! The Toronto International Vocal Arts Festival

This event is part of the Estonian Music Week (EMW) festival programme running May 22-25. With performances from folktronica to contemporary classical music, EMW is sure to become your new favourite early-summer music festival.

name: Doors Open at the Church of the Holy Trinity
description:
Celebrate with us this year’s theme “The City Is Your Playground; Get Ready to Play” as we explore play in all its joyful, sacred, and transformative forms. 

Located beside the Eaton Centre, our historic church celebrates creativity, connection, and community life. Since 1847, we have been a space for worship and action, rooted in social justice, housing advocacy, 2SLGBTQ+ inclusion, Indigenous solidarity, and care. Experience the playful spirit of our space, meet community partners who bring it to life, and join us Sunday for services in English and Spanish.

organizer.name: The Church of the Holy Trinity

name: Doors Open Toronto at MOCA
description:
Join us for two full days of free, interactive programmes, including drop-in tours, an all-ages drop-in workshop, and a Muay Thai presentation. 

Open to visitors of all-ages, explore all three floors of MOCA, with dynamic exhibitions and new commissions. Delve into the unique history of the Auto BLDG, discover the Junction Triangle neighbourhood, and investigate the architecture and parklands that make up our city.

name: Plant Fair 2025
description:
A beloved, local Plant Fair that's also a community gardens' fundraiser! A rain or shine event.

Featuring: Natives, pollinators, organic herbs & veggies, shade lovers & hard-to-find plants. Plus, a garden flea market, free gardening advice, & groovy giveaways!

Not Featuring: Anything invasive. Shop with ease knowing that nothing invasive will be on offer.

Jumping Worm Protocols: Whether you know about invasive jumping worms or not, don't fret when shopping our fair. All donated plants have been thoroughly root-washed, repotted in clean pots with commercial potting soil, and stored off the ground. 

Accessibility: Accessible space (with ramp access) can accommodate people with mobility devices as well as those bringing wagons and strollers.

See you there!

organizer.name: The Horticultural Societies of Parkdale & Toronto

name: Riverdale Farm Spring Celebration
description: Our Spring Celebration will feature sheep shearing, spinning demonstrations and children's activities throughout the day.

name: North Toronto Group of Artists Spring Fine Art Show & Sale
description:
Visit our bi-annual Spring walking tour in North Toronto, where you can meet 32 local artists exhibiting and selling their original fine art. 

Event runs rain or shine. Pets welcome. Walk, cycle or drive to see the entire tour or a portion thereof. Visit our website for the map of locations and list of participating artists.

name: "Doors Open Toronto" Artisan Market
description:
We are excited to host a market that emphasizes handcrafted and hand-produced, rather than mass made. We support local artisans and celebrate creativity! 

Our first Market of the year will be coinciding with Doors Open Toronto and an exhibition in partnership with the Contact Photography Festival. In the spirit of supporting local and small business owners, our Artisan Market is dedicated to featuring handcrafted, one-of-a-kind creations from a roster of local vendors.

Stop by the Hub to shop local artisans and discover unique handmade crafts. We also welcome you to explore our century-old green building with galleries, café, rooftop garden, and all other spaces.

name: The Libravian
description:
Meet Lynn, the lovable librarian, or “libravian” as she likes to call herself. In this whimsical adventure, audiences journey through literature, exploring stories about bravery. Through playful costumes, intricate sound design, and physical theatre.

The Libravian is a joyous celebration of books, courage, and the magic of imagination. Designed for young audiences aged 8-11, this enchanting performance is perfect for families.
image: https://secure.toronto.ca/webapps/CC/fileAPI/edc_eventcal/Copy of 8_iIr08rAnggtSj2-LPWcI3Q. Libravian Theatre Bru ¿ Anita Murphy 2021 (1).jpg

name: asses.masses
description:
The unemployed donkeys have one demand: the humans must surrender their machines and give all donkeys their jobs back. But revolution is never easy!

asses.masses is a custom-made video game about labour, technophobia and sharing the load of revolution, designed to be played from beginning to end in a live theatre. This is a full day experience with gaming as performance; an immersive, cheeky and highly original work. Brave spectators take turns at the controller to lead the herd through a post-Industrial society, where asses are valued more for their hides than their potential.

This game is as if Animal Farm meets Pokémon meets Final Fantasy: as exciting in form as it is in content. No previous gaming (or donkey) experience required.

name: Amici Chamber Ensemble: Canadian Inspirations Gala
description: Join us for an unforgettable gala to celebrate the rich and diverse musical heritage of Canada. From vibrant folk traditions to majestic landscapes, this concert captures the spirit of our nation's cultures, languages, and histories. With compositions such as Leonard Cohen’s Hallelujah, Joni Mitchell’s A Case of You and Red River Valley. Experience these dynamic and sweeping melodies, featuring our dear friend Soprano Mireille Asselin.

name: CAMH Engage's Paddles for Progress

location.name: Pickleball Tournament: Fairgrounds Racket Club, Cloverdale

description: This is the second annual event, featuring a round-robin doubles pickleball tournament, followed by a lively social party, with all proceeds supporting vital mental health initiatives.

name: Green Day - Repair, Recycle and Plant with Swansea Town Hall
description: A free community event full of Earth and family-friendly initiatives. Activities include bike repairs, The Repair Cafe, recycle my electronics, Toronto Forestry give away of trees and shrubs,  LEAF talking about planting in your back garden, Green 13 and Toronto Hydro with information on Heat Pumps and Toronto Fire Services with safety tips.
